@Mario Carneiro often the meat of the theorem is not tagged with a name, but the named theorem is often a simple corollary of a hard lemma

Sylow I:
"lemma": for each subgroup H < G of order p^i where i<n where |G| = p^n k, there is a subgroup of order p^(k+1)
"corollary": there is a subgroup of order p^n (proof: easy induction)

FTG:
"lemma": a lot of lemmas about normality and stuff, including a heavy proof of a very technical lemma that for any finite subgroup H of Aut(K) for some field K, K is galois over the fixed field K^H, of index |H|.
"theorem": fundamental theorem of galois theory (proof: easy application of the 10 lemmas above)

FTC:
"lemma": integration is linear (proof: partition refinement, etc)
"lemma": mean value theorem (proof: i don't even know)
"theorem": fundamental theorem of calculus (proof: easy application of linearity and mean value theorem)
This is true. If it makes you feel better you can call it a "main lemma"
@Kenny Lau I would not put any references to theorem numbers of the stacks project. They change very often. That is exactly what the tags were developed to solve. The tags are stable references.
So you're only proving the surjectivity of R -> prod R / I_i, however the kernel is obviously what it's supposed to be.
